item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: a race to the bottom that I'm happy to see.
where will value be captured in this stack?
I think initially by prover networks, but once this (inevitably) gets cheap + commoditized enough then the ball will be in the zk-powered apps' court...
item.dc:creator: @BJ_Dyakov

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: üéØ Key findings
- Network Halting via Mempool Spamming - IPAccount Reward Theft - Front-Running in Validator Creation - ERC721 Callback Omission - Gas Cost Optimization
The Story team was proactive and swift in addressing these issues, reflecting their strong commitment to security and transparency.
item.dc:creator: @FuzzingLabs
item.description:
üéØ Key findings

- Network Halting via Mempool Spamming
- IPAccount Reward Theft
- Front-Running in Validator Creation
- ERC721 Callback Omission
- Gas Cost Optimization

The Story team was proactive and swift in addressing these issues, reflecting their strong commitment to security and transparency.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: New high-performance zkVM by @brevis_zk just dropped!! Built using plonky3! Congrats to the team.
The beauty of zkVMs is that are no switching costs, network effects, or lock-in. Devs will just use the fastest one.
Good chance that the fastest zkVM at the end of 2025 might not have existed six months ago.
item.dc:creator: @_bfarmer
item.description:
New high-performance zkVM by @brevis_zk just dropped!! Built using plonky3! Congrats to the team.

The beauty of zkVMs is that are no switching costs, network effects, or lock-in. Devs will just use the fastest one.

Good chance that the fastest zkVM at the end of 2025 might not have existed six months ago.

item.title: Pico just disrupted the market of zkVMs. Congrats @brevis_zk. After meeting in person I was sure you guys were going to kill the market. You have very smart hard working people.

item.title: R to @fede_intern: github: https://github.com/brevis-network/pico
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: github: github.com/brevis-network/pi‚Ä¶

item.title:
zkVMs RISCV have no motto. they will constantly get replaced and they all will converge to the same solution. congrats @brevis_zk. A big new competitor joined the party.
Pico is also highly performant. Though we do not have a fully functional GPU accelerated clustering solution yet, Pico sets a new industry benchmark by achieving the world‚Äôs fastest performance on CPU‚Äîrunning 70% to 155% faster than the second-best solution among RISC0, SP1 and OpenVM.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
zkVMs RISCV have no motto. they will constantly get replaced and they all will converge to the same solution. congrats @brevis_zk. A big new competitor joined the party.

Pico is also highly performant. Though we do not have a fully functional GPU accelerated clustering solution yet, Pico sets a new industry benchmark by achieving the world‚Äôs fastest performance on CPU‚Äîrunning 70% to 155% faster than the second-best solution among RISC0, SP1 and OpenVM.

item.title:
I don‚Äôt get how some people believe that predicting the next token will be AGI.
Yes, it will be able to do amazing things but that isn‚Äôt enough to comprehend the complexity of reality.

item.title:
This is very important. @Commit_Boost is not know by most of the industry yet. It‚Äôs crucial that it becomes a public good and we don‚Äôt have private alternatives. All the stalkers should run it.
What is the current % of the network running it @Commit_Boost?

item.title:

item.title: I‚Äôm starting to think we‚Äôre losing because we chose so. It‚Äôs retarded.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: I‚Äôm starting to think we‚Äôre losing because we chose so. It‚Äôs retarded.

item.title:
One thing is that the blockchain and its foundations are credible neutral: the blockchain should be running all around the world as decentralized as possible. it‚Äôs also important that foundations have people from all around the world and we give opportunities to founders from all the world.
another thing is that we ask the founder of a company to not have a preference over the country where he lives. the US is by far the country with the most diverse complex and big capitalists. if we want crypto to win over tradfi we need to influence and work in that country. asking a founder of a company to
Bitcoin is a decentralized protocol and it shall always remain one. this doesn‚Äôt mean Bitcoin people, particularly americans, can‚Äôt or shouldn‚Äôt incentivize its country to become big adopters and supporters of the technology.
I want Ethereum to be bigger in the US as soon as possible.
I‚Äôm honestly surprised with the critics. we‚Äôre mixing the protocol with the companies and its founders. We‚Äôre losing because we want to.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
One thing is that the blockchain and its foundations are credible neutral: the blockchain should be running all around the world as decentralized as possible. it‚Äôs also important that foundations have people from all around the world and we give opportunities to founders from all the world.

another thing is that we ask the founder of a company to not have a preference over the country where he lives. the US is by far the country with the most diverse complex and big capitalists. if we want crypto to win over tradfi we need to influence and work in that country. asking a founder of a company to

Bitcoin is a decentralized protocol and it shall always remain one. this doesn‚Äôt mean Bitcoin people, particularly americans, can‚Äôt or shouldn‚Äôt incentivize its country to become big adopters and supporters of the technology.

I want Ethereum to be bigger in the US as soon as possible.

I‚Äôm honestly surprised with the critics. we‚Äôre mixing the protocol with the companies and its founders. We‚Äôre losing because we want to.

nitter.freedit.eu/kassandraETH/status/1889280012395683912#m

item.title:
I think this criticism of @aeyakovenko doesn‚Äôt make any sense. In the Ethereum community, we rightfully emphasize credible neutrality. The founder of Solana states that he doesn‚Äôt trade on-chain because he oversees the blockchain where it happens, and yet we criticize him? Come on.
Also, the fact that he‚Äôs building products for users outside his own demographic isn‚Äôt a problem. Most major stablecoins are created by Europeans and Americans, yet their greatest utility is in developing countries.
This isn‚Äôt a serious critique.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
I think this criticism of @aeyakovenko doesn‚Äôt make any sense. In the Ethereum community, we rightfully emphasize credible neutrality. The founder of Solana states that he doesn‚Äôt trade on-chain because he oversees the blockchain where it happens, and yet we criticize him? Come on.

Also, the fact that he‚Äôs building products for users outside his own demographic isn‚Äôt a problem. Most major stablecoins are created by Europeans and Americans, yet their greatest utility is in developing countries.

This isn‚Äôt a serious critique.
